manchester and new york 1891 no 203 Tuesday October 23 1711 addison phoebe pater si das hujus mihi nominis usum nec falsâ clymene culpam sub imagine celat pignora da genitor ov meet there be a loose tribe of man whom i have not yet take notice of that ramble into all the corner of this great city in order to seduce such unfortunate female as fall into they walk these abandon profligate raise up issue in every quarter of the town and very often for a valuable consideration father it upon the church-warden by this mean there be several married man who have a little family in most of the parish of london and westminster and several batchelor who be undo by a charge of child when a man once give himself this liberty of prey at large and living upon the common he find so much game in a populous city that it be surprising to consider the number which he sometimes propagate we see many a young fellow who be scarce of age that could lay he claim to the jus trium liberorum or the privilege which be grant by the roman law to all such as be father of three child : nay i have hear a rake -lrb- who -lrb- 1 -rrb- -rrb- be not quite five and twenty declare himself the father of a seventh son and very prudently determine to breed he up a physician in short the town be full of these young patriarch not to mention several batter would beau who like heedless spendthrift that squander away they estate before they be master of they have raise up they whole stock of child before marriage i must not here omit the particular whim of a impudent libertine that have a little smattering of heraldry and observe how the genealogy of great family be often draw up in the shape of tree have take a fancy to dispose of he own illegitimate issue in a figure of the same kind -- nec longum tempus et ingens exiit ad coelum ramis felicibus arbos miraturque novas fronde et non sua poma virg -lrb- 2 -rrb- the trunk of the tree be mark would with he own name will maple out of the side of it grow a large barren branch inscribe mary maple the name of he unhappy wife the head be adorn with five huge bough on the bottom of the first be write in capital character kate cole who branch out into three sprig viz william richard and rebecca sal twiford give birth to another bough that shoot up into sarah tom will and frank the third arm of the tree have only a single infant in it with a space leave for a second the parent from whom it spring be near she time when the author take this ingenious device into he head the two other great bough be very plentifully loaden with fruit of the same kind besides which there be many ornamental branch that do not bear in short a more flourishing tree never come out of the herald office what make this generation of vermin so very prolifick be the indefatigable diligence with which they apply themselves to they business a man do not undergo more watching and fatigue in a campaign than in the course of a vicious amour as it be say of some man that they make they business they pleasure these son of darkness may be say to make they pleasure they business they might conquer they corrupt inclination with half the pain they be at in gratify they nor be the invention of these man less to be admire than they industry or vigilance there be a fragment of apollodorus the comick poet -lrb- who be contemporary with menander -rrb- which be full of humor as follow : thou mayest shut up thy door say he with bar and bolt : it will be impossible for the blacksmith to make they so fast but a cat and a whoremaster will find a way through they in a word there be no head so full of stratagem as that of a libidinous man be i to propose a punishment for this infamous race of propagator it should be to send they after the second or third offence into we american colony in order to people those part of she majesty 's dominion where there be a want of inhabitant and in the phrase of diogene to plant man some country punish this crime with death but i think such a banishment would be sufficient and might turn this generative faculty to the advantage of the publick in the mean time till these gentleman may be thus dispose of i would earnestly exhort they to take care of those unfortunate creature whom they have bring into the world by these indirect method and to give they spurious child such a education as may render they more virtuous than they parent this be the best atonement they can make for they own crime and indeed the only method that be leave they to repair they past mis-carriage i would likewise desire they to consider whether they be not bind in common humanity as well as by all the obligation of religion and nature to make some provision for those whom they have not only give life to but entail would upon they -lrb- tho very unreasonably a degree of -rrb- shame and -lrb- disgrace -lrb- 3 -rrb- -rrb- and here i can not but take notice of those depraved notion which prevail among we and which must have take rise from we natural inclination to favor a vice to which we be so very prone namely that bastardy and cuckoldom should be look would upon as reproach and that the -lrb- ignominy -lrb- 4 -rrb- -rrb- which be only due to lewdness and falsehood should fall in so unreasonable a manner upon the person who -lrb- be -lrb- 5 -rrb- -rrb- innocent i have be insensibly draw into this discourse by the follow letter which be draw up with such a spirit of sincerity that i question not but the writer of it have represent he case in a true and genuine light sir i be one of those people who by the general opinion of the world be count both infamous and unhappy my father be a very eminent man in this kingdom and one who bear considerable office in it i be he son but my misfortune be that i dare not call he father nor he without shame own I as he issue i be illegitimate and therefore deprive of that endearing tenderness and unparallel would satisfaction which a good man find in the love and conversation of a parent : neither have i the opportunity to render he the duty of a son he have always carry himself at so vast a distance and with such superiority towards I that by long use i have contract a timorousness when before he which hinder I from declare my own necessity and give he to understand the inconveniency i undergo it be my misfortune to have be neither breed a scholar -lrb- a soldier -rrb- nor to -lrb- any kind of -rrb- business which render I entirely uncapable of make provision for my self without he assistance and this create a continual uneasiness in my mind fear i shall in time want bread my father if i may so call he give I but very faint assurance of do any thing for I i have hitherto live somewhat like a gentleman and it would be very hard for I to labor for my living i be in continual anxiety for my future fortune and under a great unhappiness in lose the sweet conversation and friendly advice of my parent so that i can not look upon my self otherwise than as a monster strangely spring up in nature which every one be ashamed to own i be think to be a man of some natural part and by the continual reading what you have offer the world become a admirer thereof which have draw I to make this confession at the same time hope if any thing herein shall touch you with a sense of pity you would then allow I the favor of you opinion thereupon as also what part i be unlawfully bear may claim of the man 's affection who beget I and how far in you opinion i be to be think he son or he acknowledge as my father you sentiment and advice herein will do assure you i be very much afraid of venture upon you i now like you in spite of my reason and think it a ill circumstance to owe one happiness to nothing but infatuation i can see you ogle all the young fellow who look at you and observe you eye wander after new conquest every moment you be in a publick place and yet there be such a beauty in all you look and gesture that i can not but admire you in the very act of endeavor to gain the heart of other my condition be the same with that of the lover in the _ way of the world _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- i have study you fault so long that they be become as familiar to I and i like they as well as i do my own look to it madam and consider whether you think this gay behavior will appear to I as amiable when a husband as it do now to I a lover thing be so far advance that we must proceed and i hope you will lay it to heart that it will be become in I to appear still you lover but not in you to be still my mistress gaiety in the matrimonial life be graceful in one sex but exceptionable in the other as you improve these little hint you will ascertain the happiness or uneasiness of _ madam you most obedient most humble servant _ td _ sir _ when i sit at the window and you at the other end of the room by my cousin i see you catch I look at you since you have the secret at last which i be sure you should never have know but by inadvertency what my eye say be true but it be too soon to confirm it with my hand therefore shall not subscribe my name _ sir _ there be other gentleman nearer and i know no necessity you be under to take up that flippant creature fan last night but you shall never touch a stick of mine more that be po _ philli _ to colonel r -- s -lrb- 3 -rrb- in spain before this can reach the best of husband and the fondest lover those tender name will be no more of concern to I the indisposition in which you to obey the dictate of you honor and duty leave I have increase upon I and i be acquaint by my physician i can not live a week longer at this time my spirit fail I and it be the ardent love i have for you that carry I beyond my strength and enable I to tell you the most painful thing in the prospect of death be that i must part with you but let it be a comfort to you that i have no guilt hang upon I no unrepented folly that retard I but i pass away my last hour in reflection upon the happiness we have live in together and in sorrow that it be so soon to have a end this be a frailty which i hope be so far from criminal that methink there be a kind of piety in be so unwilling to be separate from a state which be the institution of heaven and in which we have live accord to its law as we know no more of the next life but that it will be a happy one to the good and miserable to the wicked why may we not please ourselves at least to alleviate the difficulty of resign this be in imagine that we shall have a sense of what pass below and may possibly be employ in guide the step of those with whom we walk with innocence when mortal why may not i hope to go on in my usual work and tho unknown to you be assistant in all the conflict of you mind give I leave to say to you o best of man that i can not figure to myself a greater happiness than in such a employment : to be present at all the adventure to which human life be expose to administer slumber to thy eyelid in the agony of a fever to cover thy beloved face in the day of battle to go with thee a guardian angel incapable of wound or pain where i have long to attend thee when a weak a fearful woman : these my dear be the thought with which i warm my poor languid heart but indeed i be not capable under my present weakness of bear the strong agony of mind i fall into when i form to myself the grief you will be in upon you first hearing of my departure i will not dwell upon this because you kind and generous heart will be but the more afflict the more the person for whom you lament offer you consolation my last breath will if it would be a do of justice to several woman of virtue and honor whose reputation suffer by it i hope you will not think it improper to give the publick some account of this nature you must know sir i heathen on this subject as they be represent in _ plato 's _ dialogue upon prayer entitle _ alcibiade the second _ which doubtless give occasion to _ juvenal 's _ tenth satire and to the second satire of _ persius _ as the last of these author have almost transcribe the precede dialogue entitle _ alcibiade the first _ in he fourth satire the speaker in this dialogue upon prayer be _ socrate _ and _ alcibiade _ and the substance of it -lrb- when draw together out of the intricacy and digression -rrb- as follow _ socrate _ meet he pupil _ alcibiade _ as he be go to he devotions and observe he eye to be fix upon the earth with great seriousness and attention tell he that he have reason to be thoughtful on that occasion since it be possible for a man to bring down evil upon himself by he own prayer and that those thing which the god send he in answer to he petition might turn to he destruction : this say he may not only happen when a man pray for what he know be mischievous in its own nature as _ oedipus _ implore the god to sow dissension between he son but when he pray for what he believe would be for he good and against what he believe would be to he detriment this the philosopher shew must necessarily happen among we since most man be blind with ignorance prejudice or passion which hinder they from see such thing as be really beneficial to they for a instance he ask _ alcibiade _ whether he would not be thoroughly pleased and satisfied if that god to whom he be go to address himself should promise to make he the sovereign of the whole earth _ alcibiade _ answer that he should doubtless look upon such a promise as the greatest favor that he could bestow upon he _ socrate _ then ask he if after -lrb- receiving -lrb- 1 -rrb- -rrb- this great favor he would be content -lrb- ed -rrb- to lose he life or if he would receive it though he be sure he should make a ill use of it to both which question _ alcibiade _ answer in the negative socrate then shew he from the example of other how these might very probably be the effect of such a blessing he then add that other reputed piece of good-fortune as that of have a son or procure the highest post in a government be subject to the like fatal consequence which nevertheless say he man ardently desire and would not fail to pray for if they think they prayer might be effectual for the obtain of they have establish this great point that all the most apparent blessing in this life be obnoxious to such dreadful consequence and that no man know what in its event would prove to he a blessing or a curse he teach _ alcibiade _ after what manner he ought to pray in the first place he recommend to he as the model of he devotions a short prayer which a _ greek _ poet compose for the use of he friend in the follow word _ o _ jupiter _ give we those thing which be good for we whether they be such thing as we pray for or such thing as we do not pray for : and remove from we those thing which be hurtful though they be such thing as we pray for _ in the second place that he disciple may ask such thing as be expedient for he he shew he that it be absolutely necessary to apply himself to the alacrity to no kind of business but eat _ _ the fifth species of female be make out of the sea these be woman of variable uneven temper sometimes all storm and tempest sometimes all calm and sunshine constricto glorium curru non minus ignotos generosis hor sit 6 if we look abroad upon the great multitude of mankind and endeavor to trace out the principle of action in every individual it will i think seem highly probable that ambition run through the whole species and that every man in proportion to the vigor of he complection be more or less actuate by it it be indeed no uncommon thing to meet with man who by the natural bent of they inclination and without the discipline of philosophy aspire not to the height of power and grandeur who never set they heart upon a numerous train of client and dependancy nor other gay appendage of greatness who be contented with a competency and will not molest they tranquillity to gain a abundance : but it be not therefore to be conclude that such a man be not ambitious he desire may have cut out another channel and determine he to other pursuit the motive however may be still the same and in these case likewise the man may be equally push on with the desire of distinction though the pure consciousness of worthy action abstract from the view of popular applause be to a generous mind a ample reward yet the desire of distinction be doubtless implant in we nature as a additional incentive to exert we self in virtuous excellence this passion indeed like all other be frequently pervert to evil and ignoble purpose so that we may account for many of the excellency and folly of life upon the same innate principle to wit the desire of be remarkable : for this as it have be differently cultivate by education study and converse will bring forth suitable effect as it fall in with a -lrb- ingenuous -rrb- -lrb- 1 -rrb- disposition or a corrupt mind it do accordingly express itself in act of magnanimity or selfish cunning as it prudentium juv i have often think if the mind of man be lay open we should see but little difference between that of the wise man and that of the fool there be infinite _ reverie _ numberless extravagancy and a perpetual train of vanity which pass through both the great difference be that the first know how to pick and cull he thought for conversation by suppress some and communicate other talk like the weakest for indeed the talk with a friend be nothing else but _ think aloud _ _ tully _ have therefore very justly expose a precept deliver by some ancient writer that a man should live with he enemy in such a manner as might leave he room to become he friend and with he friend in such a manner that if he become he enemy it should not be in he power to hurt he the first part of this rule which regard we behavior towards a enemy be indeed very reasonable as well as very prudential but the latter part of it which regard we behavior towards a friend savor more of cunning than of discretion and would cut a man off from the greatest pleasure of life which be the freedom of conversation with a bosom friend besides that when a friend be turn into a enemy and -lrb- as the son of _ sirach _ call he -rrb- a bewrayer of secret the world be just enough to accuse the perfidiousness of the friend rather than the indiscretion of the person who confide in he discretion do not only shew it self in word but in all the circumstance of action and be like a under-agent of providence to guide and direct we in the ordinary concern of life there be many more shine quality in the mind of man possess of they without it learn be pedantry and wit impertinence virtue itself look like weakness the best part only qualify a man to be more sprightly in error and active to he own prejudice nor do discretion only make a man the master of he own part but of other men the discreet man find out the talent of those he converse with and know how to apply they to proper use accordingly if we look into particular community and division of man we may observe that it be the discreet man not the witty nor the learn nor the brave who guide the conversation and give measure to the society a man with great talent but void of discretion be like _ polyphemus _ in the fable strong and blind endue with a irresistible force which for want of sight be of no use to he though a man have all other perfection and want discretion he will be of no great consequence in the world but if he have this single talent in perfection and but a common share of other he may do what he please in he particular station of life at the same time that i think discretion the most useful talent a man can be master of i look upon cunning to be the accomplishment of little mean ungenerous mind discretion point out the noblest end to we and pursue the most proper and laudable method of attain they : cunning have only private selfish aim and stick at nothing which may make they succeed discretion have large and extended view and like a well-formed eye command a whole horizon : cunning be a kind of short-sightedness that discover the minutest object which be near at hand but be not able to discern thing at a distance discretion the more it be discover give a greater authority to the person who possess it : cunning when it be once detect lose its force and make a man incapable of bring about even those event which he might have do have he pass only for a plain man discretion be the perfection of reason and a guide to we in all the duty of life cunning be a kind of instinct that only look out after we immediate interest and welfare discretion be only find in man of strong sense and good understanding : cunning be often to be meet with in brute themselves and in person who be but the fewest remove from they in short cunning be only the mimick of discretion and may pass upon weak man in the same manner as vivacity be often mistaken for wit and gravity for wisdom the cast of mind which be natural to a discreet man make he look forward into futurity and consider what will be he condition million of age hence as well as what it be at present he know that the misery or happiness which be reserv would for he in another world lose nothing of they reality by be place at so great distance from he the object do not appear little to he because they be remote he consider that those pleasure and pain which lie hide in eternity approach nearer to he every moment and will be present with he in they full weight and measure as much as those pain and pleasure which he feel at this very instant November 24 1711 addison o pudor o pieta mart look over the letter which i have lately receive from from my correspondent i meet with the follow one which be write with such a spirit of politeness that i could not but be very much pleased with it my self and question not but it will be as acceptable to the reader mr spectator -lrb- 1 -rrb- you who be no stranger to publick assembly can not but have observe the awe they often strike on such as be oblige to exert any talent before they this be a sort of elegant distress to which ingenuous mind be the most liable and may therefore deserve some remark in you paper many a brave fellow who have put he enemy to flight in the field have be in the utmost disorder upon make a speech before a body of he friend at home : one would think there be some kind of fascination in the eye of a large circle of people when dart altogether upon one person i have see a new actor in a tragedy so bind up by it as to be scarce able to speak or move and have expect he would have die above three act before the dagger or cup of poison be bring in it would not be amiss if such a one be at first introduce as a ghost or a statue till he recover he spirit and grow fit for some living part as this sudden desertion of one self shew a diffidence which be not displease it imply at the same time the greatest respect to a audience that can be it be a sort of mute eloquence which plead for they favor much better than word could do and we find they generosity naturally move to support those who be in so much perplexity to entertain they i be extremely pleased with a late instance of this kind at the opera of _ almahide _ in the encouragement give to a young singer -lrb- 2 -rrb- whose more than ordinary concern on she first appearance recommend she no less than she agreeable voice and just performance meer bashfulness without merit be awkward and merit without modesty insolent but modest merit have a double claim to acceptance and generally meet with as many patron as beholder _ i be _ & c it be impossible that a person should exert himself to advantage in a assembly whether it be he part either to sing or speak who lie under too great oppression of modesty i remember upon talk with a friend of mine concern the force of pronunciation we discourse lead we into the enumeration of the several organ of speech which a orator ought to have in perfection as the tongue the tooth -lrb- the lip -rrb- the nose the palate and the wind-pipe upon which say my friend you have omit the most material organ of they all and that be the forehead but notwithstanding a excess of modesty obstruct the tongue and render it unfit for its office a due proportion of it be think so requisite to a orator that rhetorician have recommend it to they disciple as a particular in they art _ cicero _ tell we that he never like a orator who do not appear in some little confusion at the beginning of he speech and confess that he himself never enter upon a oration without tremble and concern it be indeed a kind of deference which be due to a great assembly and seldom fail to raise a benevolence in the audience towards the person who speak my correspondent have take notice that the bravest man often appear timorous on these occasion as indeed we may observe that there be generally no creature more impudent than a coward -- _ linguá melior sedfrigida bello dextera _ -- a bold tongue and a feeble arm be the qualification of _ drance _ in _ virgil _ as _ homer _ to express a man both timorous and sawcy make use of a kind of point which be very rarely to be meet with in he writings namely that he have the eye of a dog but the heart of a deer -lrb- 3 -rrb- a just and reasonable modesty do not only recommend eloquence but set off every great talent which a man can be possess of it heighten all the virtue which it accompany like the shades in painting it raise and round every figure and make the color more beautiful though not so glaring as they would be without it modesty be not only a ornament but also a guard to virtue it be a kind of quick and delicate _ feeling _ in the soul which make she shrink and withdraw she self from every thing that have danger in it it be such a exquisite sensibility as warn she to shun the first appearance of every thing which be hurtful i can not at present recollect either the place or time of what i be go to mention but i have read somewhere in the history of ancient _ greece _ that the woman of the country be seize with a unaccountable melancholy which dispose several of they to make away with themselves the senate after have try many expedient to prevent this self-murder which be so frequent among they publish a edict that if any woman whatever should lay violent hand upon she self she corps should be expose naked in the street and drag about the city in the most publick manner this edict immediately put a stop to the practice which be before so common we may see in this instance the strength of female modesty which be able to overcome the violence even of madness and despair the fear of shame in the fair sex be in those day more prevalent than that of death if modesty have so great a influence over we action and be in many case so impregnable a fence to virtue what can more undermine morality than that politeness which reign among the unthinking part of mankind and treat as unfashionable the most ingenuous part of we behavior which recommend impudence as good breeding and keep a man always in countenance not because he be innocent but because he be shameless _ seneca _ think modesty so great a check to vice that he prescribe to we the practice of it in secret and advise we to raise it in ourselves upon imaginary occasion when such as be real do not offer themselves for this be the meaning of he precept that when we be by ourselves and in we greatest solitude we should fancy that _ cato _ stand before we and see every thing we do in short if you banish modesty out of the world she carry away with she half the virtue that be in it after these reflection on modesty as it be a virtue i must observe that there be a vicious modesty which justly deserve to be ridicule and which those person very often discover who value themselves most upon a well-bred confidence this happen when a man be ashamed to act up to he reason and would not upon any consideration be surprize in the practice of those duty for the performance of which he be send into the world many a impudent libertine would blush to be catch in a serious discourse and would scarce be able to show he head after have disclose a religious thought decency of behavior all outward show of virtue and abhorrence of vice be carefully avoid by this set of shame-faced people as what would disparage they gayety of temper and infallibly bring they to dishonor this be such a poorness of spirit such a despicable cowardice such a degenerate abject state of mind as one would think human nature incapable of do we not meet with frequent instance of it in ordinary conversation there be another kind of vicious modesty which make a man ashamed of he person he birth he profession he poverty or the like misfortune which it be not in he choice to prevent and be not in he power to rectify if a man appear ridiculous by any of the afore-mentioned circumstance he become much more so by be out of countenance for they they should rather give he occasion to exert a noble spirit and to palliate those imperfection which be not in he power by those perfection which be or to use a very witty allusion of a eminent author he should imitate _ cæsar _ who because he head be bald cover would that defect with laurel c -lrb- footnote 1 : this letter be by john hughe -rrb- -lrb- footnote 2 : mr barbier -rrb- -lrb- footnote 3 : iliad i 225 -rrb- \* \* \* \* \* no 232 Monday November 26 1711 hughe -lrb- 1 -rrb- nihil largiundo gloriam adeptus est sallust my wise and good friend sir _ andrew freeport _ divide himself almost equally between the town and the country : he time in town be give up to the publick and the management of he private fortune and after every three or four day spend in this manner he retire for as many to he seat within a few mile of the town to the enjoyment of himself he family and he friend thus business and pleasure or rather in sir _ andrew _ labor and rest recommend each other they take they turn with so quick a vicissitude that neither become a habit or take possession of the whole man nor be it possible he should be surfeit with either i often see he at we club in good humor and yet sometimes too with a air of care in he look : but in he country retreat he be always unbent and such a companion as i could desire and therefore i seldom fail to make one with he when he be pleased to invite I the other day as soon as we be get into he chariot two or three beggar on each side hang upon the door and solicit we charity with the usual rhetorick of a sick wife or husband at home three or four helpless little child all starve with cold and hunger we be force to part with some money to get rid of they importunity and then we proceed on we journey with the blessing and acclamation of these people well then say _ sir andrew _ we go off with the prayer and good wish of the beggar and perhaps too we health will be drunk at the next ale-house : so all we shall be able to value ourselves upon be that we have promote the trade of the victualler and the excise of the government but how few ounce of wooll do we see upon the back of those poor creature and when they shall next fall in we way they will hardly be better dress would they must always live in rag to look like object of compassion if they family too be such as they be represent ti certain they can not be better clothe and must be a great deal worse fed : one would think potato should be all they bread and they drink the pure element and then what goodly customer be the farmer like to have for they wooll corn and cattle such customer and such a consumption can not choose but advance the land interest and hold up the rent of the gentleman but of all man live we merchant who live by buy and sell ought never to encourage beggar the goods which we export be indeed the product of the land but much the greatest part of they value be the labor of the people : but how much of these people labor shall we export whilst we hire they to sit still the very alms they receive from we be the wages of idleness i have often think that no man should be permit to take relief from the parish or to ask it in the street till he have first purchase as much as possible of he own livelihood by the labor of he own hand and then the publick ought only to be tax to make good the deficiency if this rule be strictly observe we should see every where such a multitude of new labourer as would in all probability reduce the price of all we manufacture it be the very life of merchandise to buy cheap and sell dear the merchant ought to make he outset as cheap as possible that he may find the greater profit upon he return and nothing will enable he to do this like the reduction of the price of labor upon all we manufacture this too would be the ready way to increase the number of we foreign market : the abatement of the price of the manufacture would pay for the carriage of it to more distant country and this consequence would be equally beneficial both to the land and trading interest as so great a addition of labor hand would produce this happy consequence both to the merchant and the gentle man we liberality to common beggar and every other obstruction to the increase of labourer must be equally pernicious to both sir _ andrew _ then go on to affirm that the reduction of the price of we manufacture by the addition of so many new hand would be no inconvenience to any man : but observe i be something startle at the assertion he make a short pause and then resume the discourse it may seem say he a paradox that the price of labor should be reduce without a abatement of wages or that wages can be abate without any inconvenience to the labourer and yet nothing be more certain than that both those thing may happen the wages of the labourer make the greatest part of the price of every thing that be useful and if in proportion with the wages the price of all other thing should be abate every labourer with less wages would be still able to purchase as many necessaries of life where then would be the inconvenience but the price of labor may be reduce by the addition of more hand to a manufacture and yet the wages of person remain as high as ever the admirable sir william petty -lrb- 2 -rrb- have give example of this in some of he writings : one of they as i remember be that of a watch which i shall endeavor to explain so as shall suit my present purpose it be certain that a single watch could not be make so cheap in proportion by one only man as a hundred watch by a hundred for as there be vast variety in the work no one person could equally suit himself to all the part of it the manufacture would be tedious and at last but clumsily perform : but if a hundred watch be to be make by a hundred man the case may be assign to one the dial to another the wheel to another the spring to another and every other part to a proper artist as there would be no need of perplexing any one person with too much variety every one would be able to perform he single part with greater skill and expedition and the hundred watch would be finish in one fourth part of the time of the first one and every one of they at one fourth part of the cost tho the wages of every man be equal the reduction of the price of the manufacture would increase the demand of it all the same hand would be still employ and as well pay the same rule will hold in the clothing the shipping and all the other trade whatsoever and thus a addition of hand to we manufacture will only reduce the price of they the labourer will still have as much wages and will consequently be enable to purchase more conveniency of life so that every interest in the nation would receive a benefit from the increase of we work people besides i see no occasion for this charity to common beggar since every beggar be a inhabitant of a parish and every parish be tax to the maintenance of they own poor -lrb- 3 -rrb- for my own part i can not be mightily please with the law which have do this which have provide better to feed than employ the poor we have a tradition from we forefather that after the first of those law be make they be insult with that famous song hang sorrow and cast away care the parish be bind to find we & c and if we will be so good-natured as to maintain they without work they can do no less in return than sing we _ the merry beggar _ what then be i against all act of charity god forbid i know of no virtue in the gospel that be in more pathetical expression recommend to we practice _ i be hungry and -lrb- ye -rrb- -lrb- 4 -rrb- give I no meat thirsty and ye give I no drink naked and ye clothe I not a stranger and ye take I not in sick and in prison and ye visit I not _ we bless savior treat the exercise or neglect of charity towards a poor man as the performance or breach of this duty towards himself i shall endeavor to obey the will of my lord and master : and therefore if a industrious man shall submit to the hardest labor and coarsest fare rather than endure the shame of take relief from the parish or ask it in the street this be the hungry the thirsty the naked and i ought to believe if any man be come hither for shelter against persecution or oppression this be the stranger and i ought to take he in if any countryman of we own be fall into the hand of infidel and life in a state of miserable captivity this be the man in prison and i should contribute to he ransom i ought to give to a hospital of invalid to recover as many useful subject as i can but i shall bestow none of my bounty upon a alms-house of idle people and for the same reason i should not think it a reproach to I if i have withhold my charity from those common beggar but we prescribe better rule than we be able to practice we be ashamed not to give into the mistaken custom of we country : but at the same time i can not but think it a reproach worse than that of common swearing that the idle and the abandon be suffer in the name of heaven and all that be sacred to extort from christian and tender mind a supply to a profligate way of life that be always to be support but never relieved -lrb- z -rrb- -lrb- 5 -rrb- -lrb- footnote 1 : or henry martyn -rrb- -lrb- footnote 2 : surveyor-general of ireland to charle ii 233 Tuesday nov 27 1711 addison -- tanquam hec sint nostrus medicina furori aut deus ille malis hominum mitescere discat virg i shall in this paper discharge myself of the promise i have make to the publick by oblige they with a translation of the little _ greek _ manuscript which be say to have be a piece of those record that be preserve in the temple of _ apollo _ upon the promontory of _ leucate _ : it be a short history of the lover leap and be inscribe _ a account of person male and female who offer up they vow in the temple of the _ pythian apollo _ in the forty sixth olympiad and leap from the promontory of _ leucate _ into the _ ionian sea _ in order to cure themselves of the passion of love _ this account be very dry in many part as only mention the name of the lover who leap the person he leap for and relate in short that he be either cure or kill or maim by the fall it indeed give the name of so many who die by it that it would have look like a bill of mortality have i translate it at full length i have therefore make a abridgment of it and only extract such particular passage as have something extraordinary either in the case or in the cure or in the fate of the person who be mention in it after this short preface take the account as follow _ battus _ the son of _ menalca _ the _ sicilian _ leap for _ bombyca _ the musician : get rid of he passion with the loss of he right leg and arm which be break in the fall _ melissa _ in love with _ daphni _ very much bruised but escape with life _ cynisca _ the wife of _ æschines _ be in love with _ lycus _ and _ æschines _ she husband be in love with _ eurillum _ -lrb- which have make this married couple very uneasy to one another for several year -rrb- both the husband and the wife take the leap by consent they both of they escape and have live very happily together ever since _ larissa _ a virgin of _ thessaly _ desert by _ plexippus _ after a courtship of three year she stand upon the brow of the promontory for some time and after have throw down a ring a bracelet and a little picture with other present which she have receive from _ plexippus _ she throw she self into the sea and be take up alive _ n b larissa _ before she leap make a offering of a silver _ cupid _ in the temple of _ apollo _ _ simaetha _ in love with _ daphni _ the _ myndian _ perish in the fall _ charixus _ the brother of _ sappho _ in love with _ rhodope _ the courtesan have spend he whole estate upon she be advise by he sister to leap in the beginning of he amour but would not hearken to she till he be reduce to he last talent be forsake by _ rhodope _ at length resolve to take the leap perish in it _ aridaeus _ a beautiful youth of _ epirus _ in love with _ praxinoe _ the wife of _ thespi _ escape without damage save only that two of he fore-tooth be strike out and he nose a little flatted _ cleora _ a widow of _ ephesus _ be inconsolable for the death of she husband be resolve to take this leap in order to get rid of she passion for he memory but be arrive at the promontory she there meet with _ dimmachus _ the _ miletian _ and after a short conversation with he lay aside the thought of she leap and marry he in the temple of _ apollo _ _ n b _ she widow weed be still to be see hang up in the western corner of the temple _ olphi _ the fisherman have receive a box on the ear from _ thestyli _ the day before and be determine to have no more to do with she leap and escape with life _ atalanta _ a old maid whose cruelty have several year before drive two or three despair lover to this leap be now in the fifty fifth year of she age and in love with a officer of _ sparta _ break she neck in the fall _ hipparchus _ be passionately fond of he own wife who be enamoured of _ bathyllus _ leap and die of he fall upon which he wife marry she gallant _ tettyx _ the dancing-master in love with _ olympium _ a athenian matron throw himself from the rock with great agility but be cripple in the fall _ diagora _ the usurer in love with he cook-maid he peep several time over the precipice but he heart misgive he he go back and marry she that evening _ cinaedus _ after have enter he own name in the pythian record be ask the name of the person whom he leap for and be ashamed to discover it he be set aside and not suffer to leap _ eunica _ a maid of _ papho _ aged nineteen in love with _ eurybate _ hurt in the fall but recover _ n b _ this be she second time of leap _ hesperus _ a young man of _ tarentum _ in love with he master daughter drown the boat not come in soon enough to he relief _ sappho _ the _ lesbian _ in love with _ phaon _ arrive at the temple of _ apollo _ habit like a bride in garment as white as snow she wear a garland of myrtle on she head and carry in she hand the little musical instrument of she own invention after have sing a hymn to _ apollo _ she hang up she garland on one side of he altar and she harp on the other she then tuck would up she vestment like a _ spartan _ virgin and amidst thousand of spectator who be anxious for she safety and offer up vow for she deliverance -lrb- march -lrb- 1 -rrb- -rrb- directly forwards to the utmost summit of the promontory where after have repeat a stanza of she own verse which we could not hear she throw herself off the rock with such a intrepidity as be never before observe in any who have attempt that dangerous leap many who be present related that they see she fall into the sea from whence she never rise again tho there be other who affirm that she never come to the bottom of she leap but that she be change into a swan as she fall and that they see she hover in the air under that shape but whether or no the whiteness and fluttering of she garment might not deceive those who look upon she or whether she might not really be metamorphose into that musical and melancholy bird be still a doubt among the _ lesbian _ _ alcæus _ the famous _ lyrick _ poet who have for some time be passionately in love with _ sappho _ arrive at the promontory of _ leucate _ that very evening in order to take the leap upon she account but hear that _ sappho _ have be there before he and that she body could be no where find he very generously lament she fall and be say to have write he hundred and twenty fifth ode upon that occasion _ leap in this olympiad _ -lrb- 250 -lrb- 2 -rrb- -rrb- after a story have be tell with some entertaining circumstance tell it over again with particulars that destroy the jest but give light into the truth of the narration this sort of veracity though it be impertinent have something amiable in it because it proceed from the love of truth even in frivolous occasion if such honest amendment do not promise a agreeable companion they do a sincere friend for which reason one should allow they so much of we time if we fall into they company as to set we right in matter that can do we no manner of harm whether the fact be one way or the other lie which be tell out of arrogance and ostentation a man should detect in he own defense because he should not be triumph over lie which be tell out of malice he should expose both for he own sake and that of the rest of mankind because every man should rise against a common enemy : but the officious liar many have argue be to be excuse because it do some man good and no man hurt the man who make more than ordinary speed from a fight in which the _ athenian _ be beat and tell they they have obtain a complete victory and put the whole city into the utmost joy and exultation be check would by the magistrate for he falshood but excuse himself by say _ o athenian _ be i you enemy because i give you two happy day this fellow do to a whole people what a acquaintance of mine do every day he live in some eminent degree to particular person he be ever lie people into good humor and as _ plato _ say it be allowable in physician to lie to they patient to keep up they spirit i be half doubtful whether my friend behavior be not as excusable he manner be to express himself surprise at the chearful countenance of a man whom he observe diffident of himself and generally by that mean make he lie a truth he will as if he do not know any -lrb- thing -rrb- -lrb- 2 -rrb- of the circumstance ask one whom he know at variance with another what be the meaning that mr such a one name he adversary do not applaud he with that heartiness which formerly he have hear he he say indeed -lrb- continue he -rrb- i would rather have that man for my friend than any man in _ england _ but for a enemy -- this melt the person he talk to who expect nothing but downright raillery from that side accord as he see he practice succeed he go to the opposite party and tell he he can not imagine how it happen that some people know one another so little you speak with so much coldness of a gentleman who say more good of you than let I tell you any man living deserve the success of one of these incident be that the next time that one of the adversary spy the other he hem after he in the publick street and they must crack a bottle at the next tavern that use to turn out of the other way to avoid one another eyeshot he will tell one beauty she be commend by another nay he will say she give the woman he speak to the preference in a particular for which she she self be admire the pleasantest confusion imaginable be make through the whole town by my friend indirect office you shall have a visit return after half a year absence and mutual railing at each other every day of that time they meet with a thousand lamentation for so long a separation each party name herself for the greater delinquent if the other can possibly be so good as to forgive she which she have no reason in the world but from the knowledge of she goodness to hope for very often a whole train of railer of each side tire they horse in set matter right which they have say during the war between the party and a whole circle of acquaintance be put into a thousand please passion and sentiment instead of the pang of anger envy detraction and malice the worst evil i ever observe this man 's falsehood occasion have be that he turn detraction into flattery he be well skilled in the manners of the world and by over-look what man really be he grounds he artifice upon what they have a mind to be upon this foundation if two distant friend be bring together and the cement seem to be weak he never rest till he find new appearance to take off all remains of ill-will and that by new misunderstanding they be thoroughly reconcile to the spectator _ devonshire nov _ 14 1711 sir there arrive in this neighborhood two day ago one of you gay gentleman of the town who be attend at he entry with a servant of he own besides a countryman he have take up for a guide excite the curiosity of the village to learn whence and what he might be the countryman -lrb- to whom they apply as most easy of access -rrb- know little more than that the gentleman come from _ london _ to travel and see fashion and be as he hear say a free-thinker : what religion that might be he could not tell and for he own part if they have not tell he the man be a free-thinker he should have guess by he way of talk he be little better than a heathen except only that he have be a good gentleman to he and make he drunk twice in one day over and above what they have bargain for i do not look upon the simplicity of this and several odd inquiry with which i shall not trouble you to be wonder at much less can i think that we youth of fine wit and enlarged understanding have any reason to laugh there be no necessity that every squire in _ great britain _ should know what the word free-thinker stand for but it be much to be wish that they who value themselves upon that conceited title be a little better instruct in what it ought to stand for and that they would not perswade themselves a man be really and truly a free-thinker in any tolerable sense meerly by virtue of he be a atheist or a infidel of any other distinction it may be doubt with good reason whether there ever be in nature a more abject slavish and bigotted generation than the tribe of _ beau esprit _ at present so prevail in this island they pretension to be free-thinker be no other than rake have to be free-liver and savage to be free-men that be they can think whatever they have a mind to and give themselves up to whatever conceit the extravagancy of they inclination or they fancy shall suggest they can think as wildly as they talk and act and will not endure that they wit should be controul by such formal thing as decency and common sense : deduction coherence consistency and all the rule of reason they accordingly disdain as too precise and mechanical for man of a liberal education this as far as i could ever learn from they writings or my own observation be a true account of the _ british _ free-thinker we visitant here who give occasion to this paper have bring with he a new system of common sense the particulars of which i be not yet acquaint with but will lose no opportunity of inform my self whether it contain any -lrb- thing -rrb- -lrb- 3 -rrb- worth mr spectator notice in the mean time sir i can not but think it would be for the good of mankind if you would take this subject into you own consideration and convince the hopeful youth of we nation that licentiousness be not freedom or if such a paradox will not be understand that a prejudice towards atheism be not impartiality _ i be sir you most humble servant _ strepitus hor there be nothing which lie more within the province of a spectator than publick show and diversion and as among these there be none which can pretend to vie with those elegant entertainment that be exhibit in we theater i think it particularly incumbent on I to take notice of every thing that be remarkable in such numerous and refined assembly it be observe that of late year there have be a certain person in the upper gallery of the playhouse who when he be please with any thing that be act upon the stage express he approbation by a loud knock upon the bench or the wainscot which may be hear over the whole theater this person be commonly know by the name of the _ trunk-maker in the upper gallery _ whether it be that the blow he give on these occasion resemble that which be often hear in the shop of such artizan or that he be suppose to have be a real trunk-maker who after the finish of he day work use to unbend he mind at these publick diversion with he hammer in he hand i can not certainly tell there be some i know who have be foolish enough to imagine it be a spirit which haunt the upper gallery and from time to time make those strange noise and the rather because he be observe to be louder than ordinary every time the ghost of _ hamlet _ appear other have report that it be a dumb man who have choose this way of utter himself when he be transport with any thing he see or hear other will have it to be the playhouse thunderer that exert himself after this manner in the upper gallery when he have nothing to do upon the roof but have make it my business to get the best information i could in a matter of this moment i find that the trunk-maker as he be commonly call be a large black man whom no body know he generally lean forward on a huge oaken plant with great attention to every thing that pass upon the stage he be never see to smile but upon hear any thing that please he he take up he staff with both hand and lay it upon the next piece of timber that stand in he way with exceed vehemence : after which he compose himself in he former posture till such time as something new set he again at work it have be observe he blow be so well time that the most judicious critick could never except against it as soon as any shine thought be express in the poet or any uncommon grace appear in the actor he smite the bench or wainscot if the audience do not concur with he he smite a second time and if the audience be not yet awake look round he with great wrath and repeat the blow a third time which never fail to produce the clap he sometimes let the audience begin the clap of themselves and at the conclusion of they applause ratify it with a single thwack he be of so great use to the play-house that it be say a former director of it upon he not be able to pay he attendance by reason of sickness keep one in pay to officiate for he till such time as he recover but the person so employ tho he lay about he with incredible violence do it in such wrong place that the audience soon find out that it be not they old friend the trunk-maker it have be remark that he have not yet exert himself with vigor this season opinion upon several innocent diversion which be in use among we and which be very proper to pass away a winter night for those who do not care to throw away they time at a opera or at the play-house publick diversion which be grow so very fashionable among we if you would recommend to we wife and daughter who read you papers with a great deal of pleasure some of those sport and pastime that may very friendly man a colonel in the army whom i be mightily oblige to for he civility that come to see I almost every night for he be not one of those giddy young fellow that can not live out of a and you would laugh you heart out to see what pain my dear take to hoodwink we so that it be impossible for we to see the least glimpse of light the poor colonel sometimes hit he nose against a post and make we die with laugh i have generally the good luck not to hurt myself but be very often above half a hour before i can catch either of they for you must know we hide ourselves up and down in corner that we may have the more sport i only give you this hint as a sample of such innocent diversion as i would have you recommend and be _ most esteemed sir you ever loving friend _ timothy doodle in no 152 to w -rrb- \* \* \* \* \* no 249 Saturday December 15 1711 addison -lrb- greek : _ gélôs akairo en brotoi deinòn kakòn _ -rrb- frag vet poet when i make choice of a subject that have not be treat on by other i throw together my reflection on it without any order or method so that they may appear rather in the looseness and freedom of a essay than in the regularity of a set discourse it be after this manner that i shall consider laughter and ridicule in my present paper man be the merriest species of the creation all above and below he be serious he see thing in a different light from other being and find he mirth -lrb- a -rrb- rise from object that perhaps cause something like pity or displeasure in higher nature laughter be indeed a very good counterpoise to the spleen and it seem but reasonable that we should be capable of receive joy from what be no real good to we since we can receive grief from what be no real evil i have in my forty-seventh paper raise a speculation on the notion of a modern philosopher -lrb- 1 -rrb- who describe the first motive of laughter to be a secret comparison which we make between we self and the person we laugh at or in other word that satisfaction which we receive from the opinion of some pre-eminence in we self when we see the absurdity of another or when we reflect on any past absurdity of we own this seem to hold in most case and we may observe that the vainest part of mankind be the most addict to this passion i have read a sermon of a conventual in the church of _ rome _ on those word of the wise man _ i say of laughter it be mad and of mirth what do it _ upon which he lay it down as a point of doctrine that laughter be the effect of original sin and that _ adam _ could not laugh before the fall laughter while it last slacken and unbrace the mind weaken the faculty and cause a kind of remissness and dissolution in all the power of the soul : and thus far it may be look upon as a weakness in the composition of human nature but if we consider the frequent relief we receive from it and how often it break the gloom which be apt to depress the mind and damp we spirit with transient unexpected gleam of joy one would take care not to grow too wise for so great a pleasure of life the talent of turn man into ridicule and expose to laughter those one converse with be the qualification of little ungenerous temper a young man with this cast of mind cut himself off from all manner of improvement every one have he flaw and weakness nay the greatest blemish be often find in the most shine character but what a absurd thing be it to pass over all the valuable part of a man and fix we attention on he infirmity to observe he imperfection more than he virtue and to make use of he for the sport of other rather than for we own improvement we therefore very often find that person the most accomplish in ridicule be those who be very shrewd at hit a blot without exert any thing masterly in themselves as there be many eminent critick who never writ a good line there be many admirable buffoon that animadvert upon every single defect in another without ever discover the least beauty of they own by this mean these unlucky little wit often gain reputation in the esteem of vulgar mind and raise themselves above person of much more laudable character if the talent of ridicule be employ to laugh man out of vice and folly it might be of some use to the world but instead of this we find that it be generally make use of to laugh man out of virtue and good sense by attack every thing that be solemn and serious decent and praiseworthy in human life we may observe that in the first age of the world when the great soul and master-piece of human nature be produce man shine by a noble simplicity of behavior and be stranger to those little embellishment which be so fashionable in we present conversation and it be very remarkable that notwithstanding we fall short at present of the ancient in poetry painting oratory history architecture and all the noble art and science which depend more upon genius than experience we exceed they as much in doggerel humor burlesque and all the trivial art of ridicule we meet with more raillery among the modern but more good sense among the ancient the two great branch of ridicule in write be comedy and burlesque the first ridicule person by draw they in they proper character the other by draw they quite unlike themselves burlesque be therefore of two kind the first represent mean person in the accoutrements of hero the other describe great person act and speak like the basest among the people _ don quixote _ be a instance of the first and _ lucian _ god of the second it be a dispute among the critick whether burlesque poetry run best in heroick verse like that of the _ dispensary _ -lrb- 2 -rrb- or in doggerel like that of _ hudibra _ i think where the low character be to be raise the heroick be the proper measure but when a hero be to be pull down and degrade it be do best in doggerel if _ hudibra _ have be set out with as much wit and humor in heroick verse as he be in doggerel he would have make a much more agreeable figure than he do though the generality of he reader be so wonderfully please with the double rhime that i do not expect many will be of my opinion in this particular i shall conclude this essay upon laughter with observe that the metaphor of laugh apply to field and meadow when they be in flower or to tree when they be in blossom run through all language which i have not observe of any other ferrea vox virg there be nothing which more astonish a foreigner and fright a country squire than the _ cry of london _ my good friend sir roger often declare that he can not get they out of he head or go to sleep for they the first week that he be in town on the contrary will honeycomb call they the _ ramage de la ville _ and prefer they to the sound of lark and nightingale with all the musick of the field and wood i have lately receive a letter from some very odd fellow upon this subject which i shall leave with my reader without say any thing further of it sir i be a man of all business and would willingly turn my head to any thing for a honest livelihood i have invent several project for raise many million of money without burthen the subject but i can not get the parliament to listen to I who look upon I forsooth as a crack and a projector so that despair to enrich either my self or my country by this publick-spiritedness i would make some proposal to you relate to a design which i have very much at heart and which may procure I -lrb- a -lrb- 1 -rrb- -rrb- handsome subsistence if you will be please to recommend it to the city of _ london _ and _ westminster _ the post i would aim at be to be comptroller-general of the _ london _ cry which be at present under no manner of rule or discipline i think i be pretty well qualify for this place as be a man of very strong lung of great insight into all the branch of we _ british _ trade and manufacture and of a competent skill in musick the cry of _ london _ may be divide into vocal and instrumental as for the latter they be at present under a very great disorder a freeman of _ london _ have the privilege of disturb a whole street for a hour together with the twanking of a brass-kettle or a frying-pan the watchman 's thump at midnight startle we in we bed as much as the breaking in of a thief the sowgelder 's horn have indeed something musical in it but this be seldom hear within the liberty i would therefore propose that no instrument of this nature should be make use of which i have not tune and license after have carefully examine in what manner it may affect the ear of she majesty 's liege subject vocal cry be of a much larger extent and indeed so full of incongruity and barbarism that we appear a distract city to foreigner who do not comprehend the meaning of such enormous outcry milk be generally sell in a note above _ elum _ and in sound so -lrb- exceed -lrb- 2 -rrb- -rrb- shrill that it often set we tooth -lrb- on -lrb- 3 -rrb- -rrb- edge the chimney-sweeper be -lrb- confine -lrb- 4 -rrb- -rrb- to no certain pitch he sometimes utter himself in the deepest base and sometimes in the sharpest treble sometimes in the highest and sometimes in the lowest note of the gamut the same observation might be make on the retailer of small-coal not to mention broken glass or brick-dust in these therefore and the like case it should be my care to sweeten and mellow the voice of these itinerant tradesman before they make they appearance in we street as also to accommodate they cry to they respective wares and to take care in particular that those may not make the most noise who have the least to sell which be very observable in the vender of card-match to whom i can not but apply that old proverb of _ much cry but little wool _ some of these last mention musician be so very loud in the sale of these trifling manufacture that a honest splenetick gentleman of my acquaintance bargain with one of they never to come into the street where he live : but what be the effect of this contract why the whole tribe of card-match-maker which frequent that quarter pass by he door the very next day in hope of be buy off after the same manner it be another great imperfection in we _ london _ cry that there be no just time nor measure observe in they we news should indeed be publish in a very quick time because it be a commodity that will not keep cold it should not however be cry with the same precipitation as fire : yet this be generally the case a bloody battle alarm the town from one end to another in a instant every motion of the _ french _ be publish in so great a hurry that one would think the enemy be at we gate this likewise i would take upon I to regulate in such a manner that there should be some distinction make between the spreading of a victory a march or a incampment a _ dutch _ a _ portugal _ or a _ spanish _ mail nor must i omit under this head those excessive alarm with which several boisterous rustick infest we street in turnip season and which be more inexcusable because these be wares which be in no danger of cool upon they hand there be other who affect a very slow time and be in my opinion much more tuneable than the former the cooper in particular swell he last note in a hollow voice that be not without its harmony nor can i forbear be inspire with a most agreeable melancholy when i hear that sad and solemn air with which the public be very often ask if they have any chair to mend you own memory may suggest to you many other lamentable ditty of the same nature in which the musick be wonderfully languish and melodious i be always please with that particular time of the year which be proper for the pickling of dill and cucumber but alas this cry like the song of the -lrb- nightingale -lrb- 5 -rrb- -rrb- be not hear above two month it would therefore be worth while to consider whether the same air might not in some case be adapt to other word it might likewise deserve we most serious consideration how far in a well-regulated city those humourist be to be tolerate who not contented with the traditional cry of they forefather have invent particular song and tune of they own : such as be not many year since the pastryman commonly know by the name of the colly-molly-puff and such as be at this day the vender of powder and wash-ball who if i be rightly inform go under the name of _ powder-watt _ i must not here omit one particular absurdity which run through this whole vociferous generation and which render they cry very often not only incommodious but altogether useless to the publick i mean that idle accomplishment which they all of they aim at of cry so as not to be understand whether or no they have learn this from several of we affect singer i will not take upon I to say but most certain it be that people know the wares they deal in rather by they tune than by they word insomuch that i have sometimes see a country boy run out to buy apple of a bellows-mender and gingerbread from a grinder of knife and scissar nay so strangely infatuate be some very eminent artist of this particular grace in a cry that none but then acquaintance be able to guess at they profession for who else can know that _ work if i have it _ should be the signification of a corn-cutter forasmuch therefore as person of this rank be seldom man of genius or capacity i think it would be very proper that some man of good sense and sound judgment should preside over these publick cry who should permit none to lift up they voice in we street that have not tuneable throat and be not only able to overcome the noise of the croud and the rattle of coach but also to vend they respective merchandize in apt phrase and in the most distinct and agreeable sound i do therefore humbly recommend my self as a person rightly qualify for this post and if i meet with fitting encouragement shall communicate some other project which i have by I that may no less conduce to the emolument of the public _ i be sir _ & c ralph 253 Thursday December 20 1711 addison indignor quicquam reprehendus non quium crasse compositum illepideve putetur sed quium nuper hor there be nothing which more denote a great mind than the abhorrence of envy and detraction this passion reign more among bad poet than among any other set of man as there be none more ambitious of fame than those who be conversant in poetry it be very natural for such as have not succeed in it to depreciate the work of those who have for since they can not raise themselves to the reputation of they fellow-writer they must endeavor to sink it to they own pitch if they would still keep themselves upon a level with they the greatest wit that ever be produce in one age live together in so good a understanding and celebrate one another with so much generosity that each of they receive a additional lustre from he contemporary and be more famous for have live with man of so extraordinary a genius than if he have himself be the -lrb- sole wonder -lrb- 1 -rrb- -rrb- of the age i need not tell my reader that i here point at the reign of _ augustus _ and i believe he will be of my opinion that neither _ virgil _ nor _ horace _ would have gain so great a reputation in the world have they not be the friend and admirer of each other indeed all the great writer of that age for whom singly we have so great a esteem stand up together as voucher for one another reputation but at the same time that _ virgil _ be celebrate by _ gallus propertius horace varius tucca _ and _ ovid _ we know that _ bavius _ and _ maevius _ be he declare foe and calumniator in we own country a man seldom set up for a poet without attack the reputation of all he brother in the art the ignorance of the modern the scribbler of the age the decay of poetry be the topick of detraction with which he make he entrance into the world : but how much more noble be the fame that be build on candor and ingenuity accord to those beautiful line of sir _ john denham _ in he poem on _ fletcher _ work but whither be i stray i need not raise trophy to thee from other men dispraise : nor be thy fame on lesser ruin build nor need thy juster title the foul guilt of eastern king who to secure they reign must have they brother son and kindred slay i be sorry to find that a author who be very justly esteem among the best judge have admit some stroak of this nature into a very fine poem i mean _ the art of criticism _ which be publish would some month since and be a master-piece in its kind -lrb- 2 -rrb- the observation follow one another like those in _ horace addison -lrb- greek : ouch ehudei diòs ophthalmós eggùs d ésti kaì parôn pónô -- incert ex stob -rrb- that i might not lose myself upon a subject of so great extent as that of fame i have treat it in a particular order and method i have first of all consider the reason why providence may have implant in we mind such a principle of action i have in the next place shewn from many consideration first that fame be a thing difficult to be obtain and easily lose secondly that it bring the ambitious man very little happiness but subject he to much uneasiness and dissatisfaction i shall in the last place shew that it hinder we from obtain a end which we have ability to acquire and which be accompany with fulness of satisfaction i need not tell my reader that i mean by this end that happiness which be reserve for we in another world which every one have ability to procure and which will bring along with it fulness of joy and pleasure for evermore how the pursuit after fame may hinder we in the attainment of this great end i shall leave the reader to collect from the three follow consideration _ first _ because the strong desire of fame breed several vicious habit in the mind _ secondly _ because many of those action which be apt to procure fame be not in they nature conducive to this we ultimate happiness _ thirdly _ because if we should allow the same action to be the proper instrument both of acquire fame and of procure this happiness they would nevertheless fail in the attainment of this last end if they proceed from a desire of the first these three proposition be self-evident to those who be verse in speculation of morality for which reason i shall not enlarge upon they but proceed to a point of the same nature which may open to we a more uncommon field of speculation from what have be already observe i think we may make a natural conclusion that it be the greatest folly to seek the praise or approbation of any be besides the supreme and that for these two reason because no other be can make a right judgment of we and esteem we accord to we merit and because we can procure no considerable benefit or advantage from the esteem and approbation of any other be in the first place no other be can make a right judgment of we and esteem we accord to we merit create being see nothing but we outside and can -lrb- therefore -rrb- only frame a judgment of we from we exterior action and behavior but how unfit these be to give we a right notion of each other perfection may appear from several consideration there be many virtue which in they own nature be incapable of any outward representation : many silent perfection in the soul of a good man which be great ornament to human nature but not able to discover themselves to the knowledge of other they be transact in private without noise or show and be only visible to the great searcher of heart what action can express the entire purity of thought which refine and sanctify a virtuous man that secret rest and contentedness of mind which give he a perfect enjoyment of he present condition that inward pleasure and complacency which he feel in do good that delight and satisfaction which he take in conjuncture of circumstance for the due exercise of it a state of poverty obscure all the virtue of liberality and munificence the patience and fortitude of a martyr or confessor lie conceal in the flourishing time of christianity some virtue be only see in affliction and some in prosperity some in a private and other in a publick capacity but the great sovereign of the world behold every perfection in its obscurity and not only see what we do but what we would do he view we behavior in every concurrence of affair and see we engage in all the possibility of action he discover the martyr and confessor without the tryal of flame and torture and will hereafter entitle many to the reward of action which they have never the opportunity of perform another reason why man can not form a right judgment of we be because the same action may be aim at different end and arise from quite contrary principle action be of so mixt a nature and so full of circumstance that as man pry into they more or less or observe some part more than other they take different hint and put contrary interpretation on they so that the same action may represent a man as hypocritical and design to one which make he appear a saint or hero to another he therefore who look upon the soul through its outward action often see it through a deceitful medium which be apt to discolor and pervert the object : so that on this account also _ he _ be the only proper judge of we perfection who do not guess at the sincerity of we intention from the goodness of we action but weigh the goodness of we action by the sincerity of we intention but further it be impossible for outward action to represent the perfection of the soul because they can never shew the strength of those principle from whence they proceed they be not adequate expression of we virtue and can only shew we what habit be in the soul without discover the degree and perfection of such habit they be at best but weak resemblance of we intention faint and imperfect copy that may acquaint we with the general design but can never express the beauty and life of the original but the great judge of all the earth know every different state and degree of human improvement from those weak stirring and tendency of the will which have not yet form themselves into regular purpose and design to the last entire finishing and consummation of a good habit he behold the first imperfect rudiment of a virtue in the soul and keep a watchful eye over it in all its progress till it have receive every grace it be capable of and appear in its full beauty and perfection thus we see that none but the supreme be can esteem we accord to we proper merit since all other must judge of we from we outward action which can never give they a just estimate of we since there be many perfection of a man which be not capable of appear in action many which allow no natural incapacity of shew themselves want a opportunity of do it or should they all meet with a opportunity of appear by action yet those action maybe misinterpret and apply to wrong principle or though they plainly discover the principle from whence they proceed they could never shew the degree strength and perfection of those principle and as the supreme be be the only proper judge of we perfection so be he the only fit rewarder of they this be a consideration that come home to we interest as the other adapt it self to we ambition and what could the most aspiring or the most selfish man desire more be he to form the notion of a be to whom he would recommend himself than such a knowledge as can discover the least appearance of perfection in he and such a goodness as will proportion a reward to it let the ambitious man therefore turn all he desire of fame this way and of mankind who see every degree of perfection in other and possess all possible perfection in himself shall proclaim he worth before man and angel and pronounce to he in the presence of the whole
