Saturday January 5 1712 addison cedite romanus scriptore cedite graius -lrb- 1 -rrb- propert there be nothing in nature -lrb- more irksome than -rrb- -lrb- 2 -rrb- general discourse especially when they turn chiefly upon word for this reason i shall wave the discussion of that point which be start some year since whether _ milton 's paradise lose _ may be call a heroick poem those who will not give it that title may call it -lrb- if they please -rrb- a _ divine poem _ it will be sufficient to its perfection if it have in it all the beauty of the highest kind of poetry and as for those who -lrb- alledge -lrb- 3 -rrb- -rrb- it be not a heroick poem they advance no more to the diminution of it than if they should say _ adam _ be not _ æneas _ nor _ eve _ _ helen _ i shall therefore examine it by the rule of epic poetry and see whether it fall short of the _ iliad _ or _ æneid _ in the beauty which be essential to that kind of write the first thing to be consider in a epic poem be the fable -lrb- 4 -rrb- which be perfect or imperfect accord as the action which it relate be more or less so this action should have three qualification in it first it should be but one action secondly it should be a entire action and thirdly it should be a great action -lrb- 5 -rrb- to consider the action of the _ iliad _ _ æneid _ and _ paradise lose _ in these three several light _ homer _ to preserve the unity of he action hasten into the midst of thing as _ horace _ have observe : -lrb- 6 -rrb- have he go up to _ leda 's egg _ or begin much later even at the rape of _ helen _ or the investing of _ troy _ it be manifest that the story of the poem would have be a series of several action he therefore open he poem with the discord of he prince and -lrb- artfully -lrb- 7 -rrb- -rrb- interweave in the several succeed part of it a account of every thing -lrb- material -rrb- which relate to -lrb- they -lrb- 8 -rrb- -rrb- and have pass before that fatal dissension after the same manner _ æneas _ make he first appearance in the _ tyrrhene _ sea and within sight of _ italy _ because the action propose to be celebrate be that of he settle himself in _ latium _ but because it be necessary for the reader to know what have happen to he in the taking of _ troy _ and in the precede part of he voyage _ virgil _ make he hero relate it by way of episode in the second and third book of the _ æneid _ the contents of both which book come before those of the first book in the thread of the story tho for preserving of this unity of action they follow they in the disposition of the poem _ milton _ in imitation of these two great poet open he _ paradise lose _ with a infernal council plot the fall of man which be the action he propose to celebrate and as for those great action which precede in point of time the battle of the angel and the creation of the world -lrb- which would have entirely destroy the unity of he principal action have he relate they in the same order that they happen -rrb- he cast they into the fifth sixth and seventh book by way of episode to this noble poem _ aristotle _ himself allow that _ homer _ have nothing to boast of as to the unity of he fable -lrb- 9 -rrb- tho at the same time that great critick and philosopher endeavor to palliate this imperfection in the _ greek _ poet by impute it in some measure to the very nature of a epic poem some have be of opinion that the _ æneid _ -lrb- also labor -lrb- 10 -rrb- -rrb- in this particular and have episode which may be look upon as excrescency rather than as part of the action on the contrary the poem which we have now under we consideration have no other episode than such as naturally arise from the subject and yet be fill with such a multitude of astonishing -lrb- incident -lrb- 11 -rrb- -rrb- that it give we at the same time a pleasure of the greatest variety and of the greatest -lrb- simplicity uniform in its nature tho diversify in the execution -lrb- 12 -rrb- -rrb- i must observe also that as _ virgil _ in the poem which be design to celebrate the original of the _ roman _ empire have describe the birth of its great rival the _ carthaginian _ commonwealth : _ milton _ with the like art in he poem on the _ fall of man _ have relate the fall of those angel who be he profess enemy besides the many other beauty in such a episode its run parallel with the great action of the poem hinder it from break the unity so much as another episode would have do that have not so great a affinity with the principal subject in short this be the same kind of beauty which the critick admire in _ the spanish frier _ or _ the double discovery _ -lrb- 13 -rrb- where the two different plot look like counter-part and copy of one another the second qualification require in the action of a epic poem be that it should be a _ entire _ action : a action be entire when it be complete in all its part or as _ aristotle _ describe it when it consist of a begin a middle and a end nothing should go before it be intermix with it or follow after it that be not relate to it as on the contrary no single step should be omit in that just and regular progress which it must be suppose to take from its original to its consummation thus we see the anger of _ achille _ in its birth its continuance and effect and _ æneas 's _ settlement in _ italy _ carry on thro all the opposition in he way to it both by sea and land the action in _ milton _ excel -lrb- i think -rrb- both the former in this particular we see it contrived in hell execute upon earth and punish by heaven the part of it be tell in the most distinct manner and grow out of one another in the most natural -lrb- order -lrb- 14 -rrb- -rrb- the third qualification of a epic poem be its _ greatness _ the anger of _ achille _ be of such consequence that it embroil the king of _ greece _ destroy the hero of _ troy _ and engage all the god in faction _ æneas 's _ settlement in _ italy _ produce the _ cæsars _ and give birth to the _ roman _ empire _ milton 's _ subject be still greater than either of the former it do not determine the fate of single person or nation but of a whole species the united power of hell be join together for the destruction of mankind which they affect in part and would have complete have not omnipotence it self interpose the principal actor be man in he greatest perfection and woman in she highest beauty they enemy be the fall angel : the messiah they friend and the almighty they protector in short every thing that be great in the whole circle of be whether within the verge of nature or out of it have a proper part assign it in this noble poem in poetry as in architecture not only the whole but the principal member and every part of they should be great i will not presume to say that the book of game in the _ æneid _ or that in the _ iliad _ be not of this nature nor to reprehend _ virgil 's _ simile of the top -lrb- 15 -rrb- and many other of the same -lrb- kind -lrb- 16 -rrb- -rrb- in the _ iliad _ as liable to any censure in this particular but i think we may say without -lrb- derogate from -lrb- 17 -rrb- -rrb- those wonderful performance that there be a unquestionable magnificence in every part of _ paradise lose _ and indeed a much greater than could have be form upon any pagan system but _ aristotle _ by the greatness of the action do not only mean that it should be great in its nature but also in its duration or in other word that it should have a due length in it as well as what we properly call greatness the just measure of this kind of magnitude he explain by the follow similitude -lrb- 18 -rrb- a animal no bigger than a mite can not appear perfect to the eye because the sight take it in at once and have only a confused idea of the whole and not a distinct idea of all its part if on the contrary you should suppose a animal of ten thousand furlong in length the eye would be so fill with a single part of it that it could not give the mind a idea of the whole what these animal be to the eye a very short or a very long action would be to the memory the first would be as it be lose and swallow up by it and the other difficult to be contain in it _ homer _ and _ virgil _ have shew they principal art in this particular the action of the _ iliad _ and that of the _ æneid _ be in themselves exceed short but be so beautifully extend and diversify by the -lrb- invention -lrb- 19 -rrb- -rrb- of _ episode _ and the machinery of god with the like poetical ornament that they make up a agreeable story sufficient to employ the memory without overcharge it _ milton 's _ action be enrich with such a variety of circumstance that i have take as much pleasure in read the contents of he book as in the best invent story i ever meet with it be possible that the tradition on which the _ iliad _ and _ æneid _ be build have more circumstance in they than the history of the _ fall of man _ as it be relate in scripture besides it be easier for _ homer _ and _ virgil _ to dash the truth with fiction as they be in no danger of offend the religion of they country by it but as for _ milton _ he have not only a very few circumstance upon which to raise he poem but be also oblige to proceed with the greatest caution in every thing that he add out of he own invention and indeed notwithstanding all the restraint he be under he have fill he story with so many surprising incident which bear so close a analogy with what be deliver in holy writ that it be capable of please the most delicate reader without give offence to the most scrupulous the modern critick have collect from several hint in the _ iliad _ and _ æneid _ the space of time which be take up by the action of each of those poem but as a great part of _ milton 's _ story be transact in region that lie out of the reach of the sun and the sphere of day it be impossible to gratify the reader with such a calculation which indeed would be more curious than instructive none of the critick either ancient or modern have lay down rule to circumscribe the action of a epic poem with any determin would number of year day or hour _ this piece of criticism useful a kind that i can not forbear add my thought to yours on that subject methink it be a misfortune that the marriage state which in its own nature be adapt to give we the compleatest happiness this life be capable of should be so uncomfortable a one to so many as it daily prove but the mischief generally proceed from the unwise choice people make for themselves and expectation of happiness from thing not capable of give it nothing but the good quality of the person beloved can be a foundation for a love of judgment and discretion and whoever expect happiness from any thing but virtue wisdom good-humour and a similitude of manners will find themselves widely mistaken but how few be there who seek after these thing and do not rather make riches they chief if not they only aim how rare be it for a man when he engage himself in the thought of marriage to place he hope of have in such a woman a constant agreeable companion one who will divide he care and double he joy who will manage that share of he estate he intrust to she conduct with prudence and frugality govern he house with oeconomy and discretion and be a ornament to himself and family where shall we find the man who look out for one who place she chief happiness in the practice of virtue and make she duty she continual pleasure no : man rather seek for money as the complement of all they desire and regardless of what kind of wife they take they think riches will be a minister to all kind of pleasure and enable they to keep mistress horse hound to drink feast and game with they companion pay they debt contract by former extravagancy or some such vile and unworthy end and indulge themselves in pleasure which be a shame and scandal to humane nature now as for the woman how few of they be there who place the happiness of they marriage in the have a wise and virtuous friend one who will be faithful and just to all and constant and loving to they who with care and diligence will look after and improve the estate and without grudging allow whatever be prudent and convenient rather how few be there who do not place they happiness in outshine other in pomp and show and that do not think within themselves when they have marry such a rich person that none of they acquaintance shall appear so fine in they equipage so adorn in they person or so magnificent in they furniture as themselves thus they head be fill with vain idea and i heartily wish i could say that equipage and show be not the chief good of so many woman as i fear it be after this manner do both sex deceive themselves and bring reflection and disgrace upon the most happy and most honorable state of life whereas if they would but correct they depraved taste moderate they ambition and place they happiness upon proper object we should not find felicity in the marriage state such a wonder in the world as it now be sir if you think these thought worth insert -lrb- among -lrb- 3 -rrb- -rrb- you own be please to give material for new speculation sometimes indeed i do not make use of the letter it self but form the hint of it into plan of my own invention sometimes i take the liberty to change the language or think homer _ tell we that the blood of the god be not real blood but only something like it so we find that the brain of a beau be not real brain but only something like it the _ pineal gland _ which many greater variety of accident the implex fable be therefore of two kind : in the first the chief actor make he way through a long series of danger and difficulty till he arrive at honor and prosperity emilium without feeling in he breast at once the glow of love and the tenderness of virtuous friendship the unstudied grace of she behavior and the please accent of she tongue insensibly draw you on the name of religion which be thus make to express itself in action accord to the nature of the constitution in which it reside : so that be we to make a judgment from appearance one would imagine religion in some be little better than sullenness and reserve in many fear in other the desponding of a melancholly complexion in other the formality of insignificant unaffecting observance in other severity in other ostentation in emilium it be a principle found in reason and enliven with hope it do not break forth into irregular fit and sally of devotion but be a uniform and consistent tenor of budgell exigite ut mores tenero ceu pollice ducat ut si quis cerâ vultum facit juv i shall give the following letter no other recommendation than by tell my reader that it come from the same hand with that of last _ Thursday _ sir i send you accord to my promise some farther thought on the education of youth in which i intend to discuss that famous question _ whether the education at a publick school or under a private tutor be to be prefer _ as some of the greatest man in most age have be of very different opinion in this matter i shall give a short account of what i think may be best urge on both side and afterwards leave every person to determine for himself it be certain from _ suetonius _ that the roman think the education of they child a business properly belong to the parent themselves and plutarch in the life of marcus cato tell we that as soon as he son be capable of learn cato would suffer no body to teach he but himself tho he have a servant name chilo who be a excellent grammarian and who teach a great many other youth on the contrary the greek seem more inclined to publick school and seminary a private education promise in the first place virtue and good-breeding a publick school manly assurance and a early knowledge in the way of the world mr locke in he celebrated treatise of education -lrb- 1 -rrb- confess that there be inconveniency to be fear on both side if say he i keep my son at home he be in danger of become my young master if i send he abroad it be scarce possible to keep he from the reign contagion of rudeness and vice he will perhaps be more innocent at home but more ignorant of the world and more sheepish when he come abroad however as this learn author assert that virtue be much more difficult to be attain than knowledge of the world and that vice be a more stubborn as well as a more dangerous fault than sheepishness he be altogether for a private education and the more so because he do not see why a youth with right management might not attain the same assurance in he father house as at a publick school to this end he advise parent to accustom they son to whatever strange face come to the house to take they with they when they visit they neighbor and to engage they in conversation with man of part and breed it may be object to this method that conversation be not the only thing necessary but that unless it be a conversation with such as be in some measure they equal in part and year there can be no room for emulation contention and several of the most lively passion of the mind which without be sometimes move by these means may possibly contract a dulness and insensibility one of the greatest writer we nation ever produce observe that a boy who form party and make himself popular in a school or a college would act the same part with equal ease in a senate or a privy council and mr osborn speak like a man verse in the way of the world affirm that the well lay and carry on of a design to rob a orchard train up a youth insensibly to caution secrecy and circumspection and fit he for matter of greater importance in short a private education seem the most natural method for the form of a those seminary i be the more inclined to this opinion have my self experience the usage of two rural master each of they very unfit for the trust they take upon they to discharge the first impose much \* \* \* \* \* no 328 Monday march 17 1712 addison nullum I a labore reclinat otium hor mr spectator as i believe this be the first complaint that ever be make to you of this nature so you be the first person i ever could prevail upon my self to lay it before when i tell you i have a healthy vigorous constitution a plentiful estate no inordinate desire and be marry to a virtuous lovely woman who neither want wit nor good-nature and by whom i have a numerous offspring to perpetuate my family you will naturally conclude I a happy man but notwithstanding these promising appearance i be so far from it that the prospect of be ruin would and undo by a sort of extravagance which of late year be in a less degree creep into every fashionable family deprive I of all the comfort of my life and render I the most anxious miserable man on earth my wife who be the only child and darling care of a indulgent mother employ would she early year in learn all those accomplishment we generally understand by good breeding and polite education she sing dance play on the lute and harpsicord paint prettily be a perfect mistress of the french tongue and have make a considerable progress in italian she be besides excellently skill would in all domestick science as preserve pickling pastry make wine of fruit of we own growth embroydering and needlework of every kind hitherto you will be apt to think there be very little cause of complaint but suspend you opinion till i have further explain would my self and then i make no question you will come over to mine you be not to imagine i find fault that she either possess or take delight in the exercise of those qualification i just now mention would ti the immoderate fondness she have to they that i lament and that what be only design would for the innocent amusement and recreation of life be become the whole business and study of hers the six month we be in town -lrb- for the year be equally divide between that and the and cherry-brandy together with innumerable sort of simple water but there be nothing i lay so much to heart as that detestable catalogue of counterfeit wine which derive they name from the fruit herb or tree of whose juice they be chiefly compound : they be loathsome to the taste and pernicious to the health and as they seldom survive the year and then be throw away under a false pretence of frugality i may affirm they stand I in more than if i entertain would all we visiter with the best burgundy and champaign coffee chocolate green imperial peco and bohea-tea seem to be trifle but when subject i shall communicate they to the reader sir if i have not be hinder by some extraordinary business i should have send you sooner my further thought upon education you may please to remember conceive boy might be make to improve in virtue as they advance in letter i know that in most of we public school vice be punish and discourage whenever it be find out but this be far from be particular person be recommend to they in gross instead of which they ought to be teach wherein such a man though great in some respects be weak and faulty in other for want of this caution a boy be often so dazzle with the lustre of a great character that he confound its beauty with its blemish and look even upon the faulty part of it with a eye of admiration i have often wonder how alexander another he might at the same time mark what be moral in any speech and how far it agree with the character of the person speak this exercise would soon strengthen he judgment in what be blameable or i take it to be the highest instance of a noble mind to bear great quality without discover in a man 's behavior any consciousness that he be superior to the rest of the world or to say it otherwise consideration to other man that he be so but as he employ those high talent for they use and service he who affect the applause and address of a multitude or assume to himself a pre-eminence upon any a cobler the same company at another night have each man burn he cravat and one perhaps whose estate would bear it have throw a long wigg and lace hat into the same fire -lrb- 2 -rrb- thus they have jest themselves stark naked and run into the street and frighted woman very successfully there be no inhabitant of any standing in covent-garden but can tell you a hundred good humor where people have come off with little blood-shed and yet scower all the witty hour of the night i know a gentleman that have several wound in the head by watch pole and have be thrice run through the body to carry on a good jest : he be very old for a man of so much good-humour but to this day he be seldom merry but he have occasion to be valiant at the same time but by the favor of these gentleman i be humbly of opinion that a man may be a very witty man and never offend one statute of this kingdom not except even that of stab the writer of play have what they call unity of time and place to give a justness to they representation and it would not be amiss if all who pretend to be companion would confine they action to the place of meeting : for a frolick carry farther may be better perform by other animal than man it be not to rid much ground or do much mischief that should denominate a pleasant fellow but that be truly frolick which be the play of the mind and consist of various and unforced sally of imagination festivity of spirit be a very uncommon talent and must proceed from a assemblage of agreeable quality in the same person : there be some few whom i think peculiarly happy in it but it be a talent one can not name in a man especially when one consider that it be never very graceful but where it be regard by he who possess it in the second place the best man that i know of for secùs in bonis ab insolenti temperatam lætitiâ moriture deli ' hor i have always prefer chearfulness to mirth the latter i consider as a act the former as a habit of the mind mirth be short and transient chearfulness fix and permanent those be often raise into the greatest transport of mirth who be subject to the greatest depression of melancholy : on the contrary chearfulness tho ' it do not give the mind such a exquisite gladness prevent we from fall into any depths of sorrow mirth be like a flash of lightning that break thro a gloom of cloud and glitter for a moment chearfulness keep up a kind of day-light in the mind and fill it with a steady and perpetual serenity man of austere principle look upon mirth as too wanton and dissolute for a state of probation and as fill with a certain triumph and insolence of heart that be inconsistent with a life which be every moment obnoxious to the greatest danger writer of this complexion have observe that the sacred person who be the great pattern of perfection be never see to laugh chearfulness of mind be not liable to any of these exception it be of a serious and compose nature it do not throw the mind into a condition improper for the present state of humanity and be very conspicuous in the character of those who be look upon as the greatest philosopher among the heathen as well as among those who have be deservedly esteem as saint and holy man among christian if we consider chearfulness in three light with regard to we self to those we converse with and to the great author of we be it will not a little recommend it self on each of these account the man who be possess of this excellent frame of mind be not only easy in he thought but a perfect master of all the power and faculty of he soul : he imagination be always clear and he judgment undisturbed : he temper be even and unruffle whether in action or in solitude he come with a relish to all those goods which nature have provide for he taste all the pleasure of the creation which be pour about he and do not feel the full weight of those accidental evil which may befal he if we consider he in relation to the person whom he converse with it naturally produce love and good-will towards he a chearful mind be not only disposed to be affable and oblige but raise the same good humor in those who come within its influence a man find himself pleased he do not know why with the chearfulness of he companion : it be like a sudden sun-shine that awaken a secret delight in the mind without she attend to it the heart rejoice of its own accord and naturally flow out into friendship and benevolence towards the person who have so kindly a effect upon it when i consider this chearful state of mind in its third relation i can not but look upon it as a constant habitual gratitude to the great author of nature a inward chearfulness be a implicit praise and thanksgiving to providence under all its dispensation it be a kind of acquiescence in the state wherein we be place and a secret approbation of the divine will in he conduct towards man there be but two thing which in my opinion can reasonably deprive we of this chearfulness of heart the first of these be the sense of guilt a man who live in a state of vice and impenitence can have no title to that evenness and tranquillity of mind which be the health of the soul and the natural effect of virtue and innocence chearfulness in a ill man deserve a harder name than language can furnish we with and be many degree beyond what we commonly call folly or madness atheism by which i mean a disbelief of a supreme be and consequently of a future state under whatsoever title it shelter it self may likewise very reasonably deprive a man of this chearfulness of temper there be something so particularly gloomy and offensive to human nature in the prospect of non-existence that i can not but wonder with many excellent writer how it be possible for a man to out-live the expectation of it for my own part i think the being of a god be so little to be doubt that it be almost the only truth we be sure of and such a truth as we meet with in every object in every occurrence and in every thought if we look into the character of this tribe of infidel we generally find they be make up of pride spleen and cavil : it be indeed no wonder that man who be uneasy to themselves should be so to the rest of the world and how be it possible for a man to be otherwise than uneasy in himself who be in danger every moment of lose he entire existence and drop into nothing the vicious man and atheist have therefore no pretence to chearfulness and would act very unreasonably should they endeavor after it it be impossible for any one to live in good-humour and enjoy he present existence who be apprehensive either of torment or of annihilation of be miserable or of not be at all after have mention would these two great principle which be destructive of chearfulness in they own nature as well as in right reason i can not think of any other that ought to banish this happy temper from a virtuous mind pain and sickness shame and reproach poverty and old age nay death it self consider the shortness of they duration and the advantage we may reap from they do not deserve the name of evil a good mind may bear up under they with fortitude with indolence and with chearfulness of heart the toss of a tempest do not discompose he which he be sure will bring he to a joyful harbor a man who use he best endeavor to live accord to the dictate of virtue and right reason have two perpetual source of chearfulness in the consideration of he own nature and of that be on whom he have a dependance if he look into himself he can not but rejoice in that existence which be so lately bestow upon he and which after million of age will be still new and still in its begin how many self-congratulation naturally arise in the mind when it reflect on this its entrance into eternity when it take a view of those improveable faculty which in a few year and even at its first set out have make so considerable a progress and which will be still receive a increase of perfection and consequently a increase of happiness the consciousness of such a be spread a perpetual diffusion of joy through the soul of a virtuous man and make he look upon himself every moment as more happy than he know how to conceive the second source of chearfulness to a good mind be its consideration of that be on whom we have we dependance and in whom though we behold he as yet but in the first faint discovery of he perfection we see every thing that we can imagine as great glorious or amiable we find we self every where uphold by he goodness and surround with a immensity of love and mercy in short we depend upon a be whose power qualify he to make we happy by a infinity of means whose goodness and truth engage he to make those happy who desire it of he and whose unchangeableness will secure we in this happiness to all eternity such consideration which every one should perpetually cherish in he thought will banish from we all that secret heaviness of heart which unthinking man be subject to when they lie under no real affliction all that anguish which we may feel from any evil that actually oppress we to which i may likewise add those little crackling of mirth and folly that be apter to betray virtue than support it and establish in we such a even and chearful temper as make we please to we self to those with whom we converse and to he depend nor from the general survey of that universe in which we be place at present but from reflection on the particular season in which this paper be write the creation be a perpetual feast to the that vernal delight which i have before take notice of natural philosophy quicken this taste of the creation and render it not only please to the imagination but to the understand it do not rest in the murmur of brook and the melody of bird in the shade of grove and wood or in the embroidery of field and meadow but consider the several end of providence which be serve by they and the wonder of divine wisdom which appear in they it heighten the pleasure of the eye and raise such a rational admiration in the soul as be little inferior to devotion it be not in the power of every one to offer up this kind of worship to the great author of nature and to indulge these more refined meditation of heart which be doubtless highly acceptable in he sight : i shall therefore conclude this short essay on that pleasure which the mind naturally conceive from the present season of the year by the recommend of a practice for which every one have sufficient ability i would have my reader endeavor those who be sad to pray and those who be merry to sing psalm the chearfulness of heart which spring up in we from the survey of nature 's work be a admirable preparation for gratitude the mind have go a great way towards praise and thanksgiving that be fill with such a secret gladness : a grateful reflection on the supreme cause who produce it sanctify it in the soul and give it its proper value such a habitual disposition of mind consecrate every field and wood turn a ordinary walk into a morning or evening sacrifice and will improve those transient gleam of joy which naturally brighten up addison ' -- dolor ipse disertum fecerat -- ' ovid as the stoick philosopher discard all passion in general they will not allow a wise man so much as to pity the affliction of another if thou seest thy friend in trouble say epictetus thou mayst put on a look of sorrow and condole with he but take care that thy sorrow be not real -lrb- 1 -rrb- the more rigid of this sect would not comply so far as to shew even such a outward appearance of grief but when one tell they of any calamity that have befall even the nearest of they acquaintance would immediately reply what be that to I if you aggravate the circumstance of the affliction and shew how one misfortune be follow by another the answer be still all this may be true but what be it to I for my own part i be of opinion compassion do not only refine and civilize humane nature but have something in it more please and agreeable than what can be meet with in such a indolent happiness such a indifference to mankind as that in which ut nemo in sese tentat descendere ' per hypocrisie at the fashionable end of the town be very different from hypocrisie in the city the modish hypocrite endeavor to appear more vicious than he really be the other kind of hypocrite more virtuous the former be afraid of every thing that have the shew of religion in it and would be think engage in many criminal gallantry and amours which he be not guilty of the latter assume a face of sanctity and cover a multitude of vice under a seeming religious deportment but there be another kind of hypocrisie which differ from both these and which i intend to make the subject of this paper : i mean that hypocrisie by which a man do not only deceive the world but very often impose on himself that hypocrisie which conceal he own heart from he and make he believe he be more virtuous than he really be and either not attend to he vice or mistake even he vice for virtue it be this fatal hypocrisie and self-deceit which be take notice of in those word who can understand he error cleanse thou I from secret fault -lrb- 1 -rrb- if the open professor of impiety deserve the utmost application and endeavor of moral writer to recover they from vice and folly how much more may those lay a claim to they care and compassion who be walk in the path of death while they fancy themselves engage in a course of virtue i shall endeavor therefore to lay down some rule for the discovery of those vice that lurk in the secret corner of the soul and to show my reader those method by which he may arrive at a true and impartial knowledge of himself the usual means prescribe for this purpose be to examine we self by the rule which be lay down for we direction in sacred writ and to compare we life with the life of that person who act up to the perfection of human nature and be the standing example as well as the great guide and instructor of those who receive he doctrine though these two head can not be too much insist upon i shall but just mention they since they have be handle by many great and eminent writer i would therefore propose the follow method to the consideration of such as would find out they secret fault and make a true estimate of themselves in the first place let they consider well what be the character which they bear among they enemy we friend very often flatter we as much as we own heart they either do not see we fault or conceal they from we or soften they by they representation after such a manner that we think they too trivial to be take notice of a adversary on the contrary make a stricter search into we discover every flaw and imperfection in we temper and though he malice may set they in too strong a light it have generally some ground for what it advance a friend exaggerate a man 's virtue a enemy inflame he crime a wise man should give a just attention to both of they so far as they may tend to the improvement of the one and diminution of the other plutarch have write a essay on the and open we eye to several blemish and defect in we life and conversation which we should not have observe without the help of such ill-natured monitor in order likewise to come at a true knowledge of we self we should consider on the other hand how far we may deserve the praise and approbation which the world bestow upon we : whether the action they celebrate proceed from laudable and worthy motive and how far we be really possess of the virtue which gain we applause among those with whom we converse such a reflection be absolutely necessary if we consider how apt we be either to value or condemn ourselves by the opinion of other and to sacrifice the report of we own heart to the judgment of the world in the next place that we may not deceive we self in a point of so much importance we should not lay too great a stress on any suppose virtue we possess that be of a doubtful nature : and such we may esteem all those in which multitude of man dissent from we who be as good and wise as we self we should always act with great cautiousness and circumspection in point where it be not impossible that we may be deceive intemperate zeal bigotry and persecution for any party or opinion how praiseworthy soever they may appear to weak man of we own principle produce infinite calamity among mankind and be highly criminal in they own nature and yet how many person eminent for piety suffer it in its height and violence and at the same time be innocent we should likewise be very apprehensive of those action which proceed from natural constitution favorite passion particular education or whatever promote we worldly interest or advantage in these and the like case a man 's judgment be easily pervert and a wrong bias hang upon he mind these be the inlet of prejudice the unguarded avenue of man follow they passion as naturally as light do heat or as any other effect flow from its cause reason must be employ in adjust the passion but they must ever remain the principle of action the strange and absurd variety that be so apparent in man 's action shew plainly they can never proceed immediately from reason so pure a fountain emit no such troubled water : they must necessarily arise from the passion which be to the mind as the wind to a ship they only can move it and they too often destroy it if fair and gentle they guide it into the harbor if contrary and furious they overset it in the wave : in the same manner be the mind assist or endanger by the passion reason must then take the place of pilot and can never fail of secure she charge if she be not want to she self : the strength of the passion will never be accept as a excuse for comply with they they be design for subjection and if a man suffer they to get the upper hand he then betray the liberty of he own soul as tyrant miser the proud malicious and ill-natured might be change as a consequence of this original all passion be in all man but all appear not in all constitution education custom of the country bear and dye with we to some they be mild easie and gentle to other wayward and unruly yet never too strong for the rein of reason and the guidance of judgment we may generally observe a pretty nice
